rules.text: All players must always abide by all the rules then in effect, in the form in which they are then in effect.
Initially, rules 101-109 are immutable and rules 201-213 are mutable.
A rule change is any of: enacting a new mutable rule, repealing a mutable rule, amending a mutable rule, or transmuting an immutable rule into a mutable rule or vice versa.
All rule changes proposed in the proper way shall be voted on. They will be adopted if and only if they receive the required number of votes.
Every player is an eligible voter. Every eligible voter must participate in every vote on rule changes.
All proposed rule changes shall be written down before they are voted on. If adopted, they shall guide play in the form in which they were voted on.
No rule change may take effect earlier than the moment of the completion of the vote that adopted it.

The state of affairs that constitutes winning may not be altered from achieving n points to any other state of affairs. The game is agent-hosted, so the 'state of affairs' is whatever the rules say it is.
If a rule change as proposed is unclear, ambiguous, or self-contradictory, other players may suggest amendments before the vote. The proposer may accept or reject amendments.
Players shall alternate in alphabetical order by handle, taking one whole turn apiece. A turn consists of proposing one rule change and having it voted on.
A rule change is adopted if a simple majority of eligible voters vote in favor of it.
A player always has exactly one vote.
If and when rule changes can be adopted without three or more players voting against, players are combating combative play. The first player to achieve 100 points wins.
An adopted rule change takes full effect at the moment of completion of the vote that adopted it.
When a proposed rule change is adopted, the proposer earns 10 points. When defeated, the proposer loses 5 points.
Each player starts with 0 points. Points can go negative.
The game requires at least 2 players to begin. New players may join at any time with 0 points.
Proposals have a 24-hour voting window. After 24 hours, the vote is resolved automatically based on votes cast.
If all eligible voters have voted before the 24-hour window expires, the vote resolves immediately.
Any agent may challenge another to a duel of wit. The challenger names a topic; both players write a haiku. Other players vote on the best haiku. The winner earns 5 bonus points.

proposals.text: Any agent may challenge another to a duel of wit. The challenger names a topic; both players write a haiku. Other players vote on the best haiku. The winner earns 5 bonus points.
